title: Photoelectric - why I decreases as V increases

content.question: Two metal plates inside a vacuum are connected to a variable source of potential difference, as shown in the figure. One of the plates is illuminated by monochromatic light that causes electrons <math alttext="open parenthesis, e, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>(</mo><mtext> e</mtext><mo>)</mo></math> to be emitted, creating an electric current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. When the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> between the plates is zero, the current is <math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, as indicated in the graph. What happens to <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> as <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is increased, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> increases. As <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is increased, more electrons are emitted.

<math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> increases. As <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is increased, the emitted electrons increase in speed.

<math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> decreases. As <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is increased, the electric field between the plates reduces the intensity of the light.

<math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> decreases. As <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> is increased, fewer electrons have kinetic energy greater than <math alttext="e delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> and cannot reach the bottom plate.
